chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should keep elections run by the states but make the presidency track the will of voters more consistently by reducing winner‑take‑all incentives and swing‑state overfocus. A broadly acceptable path is to encourage proportional allocation of electors (with neutral districting rules where districts are used) and set a clear trigger for adopting a popular‑vote‑based mechanism once participating states represent a durable, bipartisan supermajority. Any change should be paired with nationwide minimum standards for voter access, paper records, risk‑limiting audits, and automatic recount/certification timelines, plus enforceable limits on faithless electors and partisan interference.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Pursue an incremental reform that keeps states administering elections but makes presidential outcomes track the national popular will more closely by reducing winner‑take‑all (e.g., proportional or district allocation of electors) and enabling a broadly supported National Popular Vote compact once clear safeguards are in place. Pair any structural change with uniform minimum standards for ballot access and secure counting—paper ballots, routine risk‑limiting audits, transparent certification, and automatic recount triggers—plus clear rules against faithless electors. Where feasible, pilot ranked‑choice voting to reduce spoiler effects and encourage broad coalitions, while adding anti‑gerrymandering/independent redistricting protections if district methods are used.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should keep states running elections but make presidential outcomes track voter preferences more fairly by reducing winner‑take‑all distortions—through proportional elector allocation and/or a widely adopted interstate compact tied to the national popular vote. Any change should come with simple, uniform safeguards everyone can trust: paper ballots, routine audits, clear recount triggers, and enforceable rules against faithless electors. A phased rollout with bipartisan oversight and attention to rural and small‑state concerns can improve legitimacy while avoiding abrupt, partisan shifts.
